Technical Assistance Subproject Report
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 54111-007 
Transaction Technical Assistance Cluster (C-TRTA) 
October 2021  
 
 
 
 
 
Preparing and Implementing Gender-Inclusive 
Projects in Central and West Asia 
Subproject 3: Integrating Gender Design Features in 
Project Preparation, Supporting Monitoring, and 
Reporting on Gender Equality Results in Central and 
West Asia Operations
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –    Asian Development Bank  
  COVID-19  ‒    coronavirus disease 
  CWRD  ‒    Central and West Asia Department 
  EGM  –    effective gender mainstreaming 
  GEN  –    gender equity theme 
  GAP  –    gender action plan 
  TA  –    technical assistance 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
              In this report, "$" refers to United States dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation 
of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

CONTENTS 
Page 
 
I.  BACKGROUND  1 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE SUBPROJECT  1 
A.  Subproject Scope  1 
B.  Subproject Outputs and Activities  2 
C.  Subproject Cost and Financing  4 
D.  Subproject Implementation Arrangements  4

3.  Summary of Corresponding Ongoing Projects   8 
4.  List of Linked Documents  14

I.  BACKGROUND  
 
1.  The transaction technical assistance (TA) cluster was approved on 8 April 2020 in the 
amount of $3,000,000 which is being financed on a grant basis by the Asian Development Bank’s 
(ADB) Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF) and is expected to be completed on 31 
December 2022.1 The overall outcome of the TA cluster is gender mainstreaming in Central and 
West Asia operations expanded and improved. The outputs are (i) gender-inclusive components 
in sovereign projects and programs incorporated; and (ii) developing member countries’ capacity 
for gender action plan implementation and monitoring of gender equality results enhanced. There 
are twelve subprojects in the TA cluster. Each subproject will contribute to deliver the gender 
outputs of the ensuing loan that it will support, and this will be specified in each subproject 
proposal. The TA cluster’s risk categorization is complex. 
 
2.  Of the twelve subprojects in the TA cluster, four subprojects are ongoing while one 
subproject is completed (Appendix 2). Six  subprojects will be  processed  and  implemented 
following the processing milestones of the respective loan/grant projects that the subprojects will 
support. One of the subprojects will support integration of gender in all projects and monitor the 
implementation of project gender action plans. As of 22 September 2021, a total of $1,500,000 
representing 50% of the total TA cluster amount has been committed, of which $407,187 or 27.1% 
has been disbursed.2 Total uncommitted funds stand at $1,500,000 which will be utilized for the 
remaining subprojects to be processed. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE SUBPROJECT 
 
A.  Subproject Scope 
 
3.  The Central and West Asia Department (CWRD) continuously strives to increase the 
number of gender mainstreamed projects in its portfolio, especially in the more challenging 
sectors of energy, finance, governance, and transport. As of 3 September 2021, the CWRD 
portfolio  includes  142  projects  supporting  gender  mainstreaming,  of  which  72  projects  are 
categorized as gender equity theme (GEN) and effective gender mainstreaming (EGM).3 The 
GEN/EGM-categorized projects include 6 energy projects (8%), 7 finance projects (10%), 3 public 
sector management projects (4%), and 11 transport projects (15%).4 Of the other GEN/EGM 
categorized projects, water and other urban services projects comprise 22%, agriculture projects 
constitute 17%, and projects in the health and education sectors comprise 14% and 10%, 
respectively. CWRD’s gender mainstreaming performance at-entry has risen substantially from 
51% in 2019 to 81% in 2020 when the TA cluster started implementation.5 
 
4.  The  coronavirus  disease  (COVID-19)  pandemic  poses  challenges  for  gender 
mainstreaming during project processing, implementation, monitoring, and reporting. Restricted 
mobility remains one of the greatest challenges, exacerbating already existing concerns, such as 
poverty, gender inequality, and social exclusion. Gender interventions designed in pre-COVID 
 
1  ADB. 2019. C-TRTA 0046-REG: Preparing and Implementing Gender Inclusive Projects in Central and West Asia. 
Manila.    
2   Please refer to Appendix 2 for the complete discussion of the status of implementation of the ongoing subrpojects.  
3  Data from Contract Awards and Disbursements as of 3 September 2021. There are 17 project readiness financing 
(PRFs) and special assistance grants (SAGs) that are not counted for gender. 
4  The percentages were computed based on the total number of GEN/EGM categorized projects.  
5  The increase in gender mainstreaming performance at-entry was also due to the substantial number COVID-19 
related projects. Of the 23 projects committed in 2020, 12 (52%) of GEN/EGM- categorized projects) were COVID-
19 related response projects under the public sector management (PSM) (8 projects) and health sector (4 projects).

2 
situations may not be enough to address the targeted gender issues in the current COVID 
situation. Continuous capacity development and technical guidance to executing/implementing 
agencies on the implementation, monitoring, and reporting of gender action plans (GAPs) need 
to be sustained amidst the evolving new normal.  
 
5.  Subproject 3 will continue to support gender mainstreaming operations in Central and 
West Asia.6 The subproject will assist projects in the integration of gender design features to meet 
GEN/EGM requirements in the current COVID context. It will determine key gender actions to 
address gender issues specific to the project scope that are aligned with the pillar of ADB’s 
operational  plan  for  gender  equality.7 To  meet  EGM  requirements,  this  will  include  the 
development of subprojects that will provide gender mainstreaming TA support to specific loan 
projects in the difficult sectors of energy, transport, and public finance. The subproject will also 
carry on with the activities of subprojects 1 and 2, specifically, support to the implementation of 
GAPs, collection and review of semi-annual GAP updates, and reporting on gender equality 
results through the preparation of gender sections for project completion reports. Subproject 3 
will further refine the gender database that was developed under Subproject 2 and conduct 
training/s on populating the fields with relevant data from the GAPs of completed projects that 
align  with  the  gender  indicators  in  the  ADB Corporate  Results  Framework,  as  well  as  on 
generating reports.8 The subproject will also conduct an assessment of the 3-year implementation 
of  the  TA  cluster  and  look  into  the  challenges,  lessons  learned,  and  ways  forward  in 
mainstreaming gender in ADB operations. This will include identifying potential projects for gender 
mainstreaming and other activities to be included in a future cluster TRTA. The subproject will 
support gender capacity building of executing and implementing agencies of ADB projects to 
enhance implementation of project GAPs and monitoring and reporting on gender equality results. 
Such capacity building activities will include in-country workshops and a subregional workshop.

4 
 
C.  Subproject Cost and Financing 
 
7.  The TA subproject is estimated to cost $415,000 which will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund ($208,000 TASF-7 and $207,000 TASF-other 
sources).9 The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1.  
 
D.  Subproject Implementation Arrangements 
 
8.  ADB will administer the subproject. The Portfolio, Results, Safeguards, and Gender Unit 
(PSG) in CWRD will be responsible for administering the subproject in close coordination with 
resident missions and sector divisions. It will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants. The 
subproject will be implemented from October 2021 to December 2022.  
 
Table 2: Subproject Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative  October 2021–December 2022

Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
9.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants to support the implementation of 
the subprojects. These will comprise (i) 36 person-months of individual international inputs, of 
which 12 person-months will be for Azerbaijan and Pakistan, 12 person-months for Kazakshtan, 
Kyrgyz Republic, and Turkmenistan, and 12 person-months of individual international inputs to 
be based in ADB headquarters (one full-time) and (ii) 36 person-months of individual national 
inputs  (12  person-months  each  to  be  based  in  Pakistan,  Tajikistan,  and  Armenia).    The 
procurement of consulting services will be carried out in accordance with “ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017 as amended from time to time) and associated staff instructions.10 
 
 
 
9  This includes TASF savings from TASF-V and TASF-other sources.
